questions.text: When administering spinal anesthesia, the order in which nerve fibers are blocked is critical for the anesthesiologist to predict the effects on the patient. Which of the following represents the correct sequence of nerve fiber blockade post-spinal anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Autonomic > Sensory > Motor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During spinal anesthesia, nerve fibers are affected in a characteristic sequence due to their size and myelination. Autonomic fibers are generally blocked first due to their smaller size and lack of myelin, followed by sensory fibers that transmit pain and temperature sensations. Motor fibers are larger and heavily myelinated, making them more resistant to the anesthetic agent, and thus, they are the last to be blocked.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The sequence of nerve fiber blockade following spinal anesthesia typically progresses from autonomic to sensory and finally to motor fibers. This order is essential for planning perioperative management and anticipating changes in patient condition during surgery.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure, a patient exhibits signs of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), presenting with CNS and cardiovascular symptoms after receiving a local anesthetic. What is the recommended initial treatment for this emergency?

  • • Local anesthetic systemic toxicity can occur when there is an elevated blood level of a local anesthetic, leading to central nervous system and cardiovascular manifestations. questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of the Phases:
  • • Phase I : Respiratory Baseline This phase corresponds to the beginning of exhalation, where the air coming out of the patient is from the dead space (areas of the lungs that do not participate in gas exchange, such as the trachea and bronchi), and should contain no CO2. The CO2 level during this phase should be 0 mmHg. Phase II : Expiratory Upstroke This phase represents the mixing of dead space air with alveolar air. The rapid rise in CO2 levels occurs as the exhaled air transitions from dead space air to alveolar air. Phase III : Alveolar Plateau The alveolar plateau represents the exhalation of alveolar gas , where CO2 levels plateau as the majority of the air comes from the alveoli, which are rich in CO2. This phase is used to measure the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), which is the concentration of CO2 at the end of expiration. This value is an important parameter in anesthesia and critical care. Phase 0 : Inspiratory Downstroke This phase occurs during the beginning of inspiration, where fresh gas enters the airways, and the CO2 concentration rapidly falls back to zero.
